title: Business and Economics Lexicon
description: Specialized vocabulary for business, finance, and economic discourse

items.definition: The gradual reduction of debt through periodic payments; spreading costs over time
items.example: The amortization schedule shows the loan will be fully paid off in 30 years.

items.definition: The use of borrowed capital to increase potential return; strategic advantage
items.example: The company used financial leverage to fund its expansion into Asian markets.

items.definition: The availability of liquid assets; how quickly assets can be converted to cash
items.example: During the crisis, many banks faced severe liquidity shortages.

items.definition: The practice of spreading investments to reduce risk
items.example: Portfolio diversification helps protect against market volatility.

items.definition: The decrease in value of an asset over time; currency value decline
items.example: The depreciation of the currency made exports more competitive.

items.definition: A person or group with interest or concern in an organization
items.example: The CEO met with key stakeholders to discuss the merger proposal.

items.definition: The act of gaining possession, especially of a company or asset
items.example: The acquisition of the startup gave them access to cutting-edge technology.

items.definition: A standard or point of reference against which things may be compared
items.example: The S&P 500 serves as a benchmark for measuring portfolio performance.
